Expected result:
It's easy enough to set gap cursor on the right side of the table
And gap cursor is visible in that state
On Android we have an additional issue regarding to the gap cursor: the keyboard disappears when we finally able to set the gap cursor on the right side of the table

content.text: I just copied a page, it had a 5 even column table. I deleted a column, and instead of the table resizing to be 4 even columns, columns A,B, and C remained the same size, and column D was now double width (the old width of column D+E). What I wanted was 4 even columns, so as a potential work around, I deleted column D to see what would happen. Huzzah! I now had 3 evenly sized columns. At this point I assumed I was on the path to victory. I inserted a new column D again, thinking I'd get 4 even column sizes. Alas, I did not. I got a min width column D this time where I could fit 4 characters per line. In a rage of panic, I hit undo a few times, which in turn caused my table to disappear completely and the "something went wrong" dialog to appear in the top left corner.

content.text: The HTML -> ADF transformation for tables is sorta buggy as the HTML used by Jira for tables has an extra div wrapping the table. The editor-jira-transformer code doesn't account for that extra div around the `<table>` and breaks when trying to transform it.
So as an example,

Heading 1 Heading 2
Col A1 Col A2

Fails to transform because of the outermost div. But if that HTML is passed to the transformer but with those divs deleted (i.e. the outermost tags are <table>), its properly transformed into an ADF table.

fields.summary: Fix Table transformation issue for Jira

content.text: This issue was raised by
in the #help-fabric-editor Slack channel on the 19th of Jan.
There were two problems that were reported - typed characters being repeated and added out of order; and an inability to publish the document. These problems were seen on
https://hello.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IMKT/pages/edit-v2/384580934?draftShareId=115a825f-6756-4c9f-9036-2bf425fb06d2
It
is
likely that Synchrony is responsible for the above behaviour... however (:wink

I looked into the Synchrony history for the page and there are many thousand Synchrony revisions that have been created and I believe Synchrony was simply failing to keep up due to this excess load. In among the legitimate revisions are many revisions containing the following step:
{"stepType":"replace","from":X,"to":Y,"slice":{"content":[{"type":"tableRow"}]}}
Interestingly, while a step was generated (and Synchrony dutifully produced a new revision of the document), the actual document state has not changed, so these revisions are superfluous.
I've created a ticket for synchrony (
https://product-fabric.atlassian.net/browse/CS-758)

to simply discard any changes that don't modify the document state, but it would be good to understand why they are occurring in the first place. I don't recall them appearing before, and the current suspicion is that they have something to do with column resizing (note that the step is attempting to include a tableRow with no cells in it, perhaps this isn't handled correctly somewhere?).

content.text: The Jira issues macro is one example, but presumably there are others. The extension is hard-coding a width, which causes it to go outside of its parent (tested on panels, bodied extension, and panels).
While the products themselves should never return a fixed width, we should enforce 100% of container width. Presumably we should make them go into overflow mode.
Original report:
Pasting a jira issues macro table in an expand causes the macro to bleed over the expand panels in edit mode
See:
https://cl.ly/489f16b2f0e7
version: editor-core@86.0.7 (86.0.7)
product: confluence
Browser: Chrome 69.0.3497.100
OS: Mac OS X 10_13_6
